019/**
020 * A text generator for producing sentences and/or words in nonsense languages that fit a theme. This does not use an
021 * existing word list as a basis for its output, so it may or may not produce existing words occasionally, but you can
022 * safely assume it won't generate a meaningful sentence except in the absolute unlikeliest of cases.
023 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 11/29/2015.
024 *
025 * @author Tommy Ettinger
026 */
027
028public class FakeLanguageGen implements Serializable {
029    private static final long serialVersionUID = -2396642435461186352L;
030    public final String[] openingVowels, midVowels, openingConsonants, midConsonants, closingConsonants,
031            vowelSplitters, closingSyllables;
032    public final boolean clean;
033    //public final IntDoubleOrderedMap syllableFrequencies;
034    public final double[] syllableFrequencies;
035    protected double totalSyllableFrequency = 0.0;
036    public final double vowelStartFrequency, vowelEndFrequency, vowelSplitFrequency, syllableEndFrequency;
037    public final Pattern[] sanityChecks;
038    public ArrayList<Modifier> modifiers;
039    public static final GWTRNG srng = new GWTRNG();
040    private static final OrderedMap<String, FakeLanguageGen> registry = new OrderedMap<>(64, Hashers.caseInsensitiveStringHasher);
041    protected String summary = null;
042    private String name = "Nameless Language";
043    private static transient StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(20), ender = new StringBuilder(12),
044            ssb = new StringBuilder(80);
045    /**
046     * A pattern String that will match any vowel FakeLanguageGen can produce out-of-the-box, including Latin, Greek,
047     * and Cyrillic; for use when a String will be interpreted as a regex (as in {@link FakeLanguageGen.Alteration}).
048     */
049    public static final String anyVowel = "[àáâãäåæāăąǻǽaèéêëēĕėęěeìíîïĩīĭįıiòóôõöøōŏőœǿoùúûüũūŭůűųuýÿŷỳyαοειυωаеёийоуъыэюя]",
050    /**
051     * A pattern String that will match one or more of any vowels FakeLanguageGen can produce out-of-the-box, including
052     * Latin, Greek, and Cyrillic; for use when a String will be interpreted as a regex (as in 
053     * {@link FakeLanguageGen.Alteration}).
054     */
055    anyVowelCluster = anyVowel + '+',
056    /**
057     * A pattern String that will match any consonant FakeLanguageGen can produce out-of-the-box, including Latin,
058     * Greek, and Cyrillic; for use when a String will be interpreted as a regex (as in
059     * {@link FakeLanguageGen.Alteration}).
060     */
061    anyConsonant = "[bcçćĉċčdþðďđfgĝğġģhĥħjĵȷkķlĺļľŀłmnñńņňŋpqrŕŗřsśŝşšștţťțvwŵẁẃẅxyýÿŷỳzźżžρσζτκχνθμπψβλγφξςбвгдклпрстфхцжмнзчшщ]",
062    /**
063     * A pattern String that will match one or more of any consonants FakeLanguageGen can produce out-of-the-box,
064     * including Latin, Greek, and Cyrillic; for use when a String will be interpreted as a regex (as in
065     * {@link FakeLanguageGen.Alteration}).
066     */
067    anyConsonantCluster = anyConsonant + '+';
068    protected static final Pattern repeats = Pattern.compile("(.)\\1+"),
069            vowelClusters = Pattern.compile(anyVowelCluster, REFlags.IGNORE_CASE | REFlags.UNICODE),
070            consonantClusters = Pattern.compile(anyConsonantCluster, REFlags.IGNORE_CASE | REFlags.UNICODE);

081    private static final Pattern[]
082            vulgarChecks = new Pattern[]
083            {
084                    //17 is REFlags.UNICODE | REFlags.IGNORE_CASE
085                    Pattern.compile("[sξζzkкκcсς][hнlι].{1,3}[dtтτΓг]", 17),
086                    Pattern.compile("(?:(?:[pрρ][hн])|[fd]).{1,3}[kкκcсςxхжχq]", 17), // lots of these end in a 'k' sound, huh
087                    Pattern.compile("[kкκcсςСQq][uμυνvhн]{1,3}[kкκcсςxхжχqmм]", 17),
088                    Pattern.compile("[bъыбвβЪЫБ].?[iτιyуλγУ].?[cсς]", 17),
089                    Pattern.compile("[hн][^aаαΛeезξεЗΣiτιyуλγУ][^aаαΛeезξεЗΣiτιyуλγУ]?[rяΓ]", 17),
090                    Pattern.compile("[tтτΓгcсς][iτιyуλγУ][tтτΓг]+$", 17),
091                    Pattern.compile("(?:(?:[pрρ][hн])|f)[aаαΛhн]{1,}[rяΓ][tтτΓг]", 17),
092                    Pattern.compile("[Ssξζzcсς][hн][iτιyуλγУ].?[sξζzcсς]", 17),
093                    Pattern.compile("[aаαΛ][nи][aаαΛeезξεЗΣiτιyуλγУoоюσοuμυνv]{1,2}[Ssξlιζz]", 17),
094                    Pattern.compile("[aаαΛ]([sξζz]{2})", 17),
095                    Pattern.compile("[kкκcсςСQq][hн]?[uμυνv]([hн]?)[nи]+[tтτΓг]", 17),
096                    Pattern.compile("[nиfvν]..?[jg]", 17), // might as well remove two possible slurs and a body part with one check
097                    Pattern.compile("[pрρ](?:(?:([eезξεЗΣoоюσοuμυνv])\\1)|(?:[eезξεЗΣiτιyуλγУuμυνv]+[sξζz]))", 17), // the grab bag of juvenile words
098                    Pattern.compile("[mм][hнwψшщ]?..?[rяΓ].?d", 17), // should pick up the #1 obscenity from Spanish and French
099                    Pattern.compile("[g][hн]?[aаαАΑΛeеёзξεЕЁЗΕΣ][yуλγУeеёзξεЕЁЗΕΣ]", 17), // could be inappropriate for random text
100                    Pattern.compile("[wψшщuμυνv](?:[hн]?)[aаαΛeеёзξεЗΕΣoоюσοuμυνv](?:[nи]+)[gkкκcсςxхжχq]", 17)
101            },
102            genericSanityChecks = new Pattern[]
103                    {
104                            Pattern.compile("[AEIOUaeiou]{3}"),
105                            Pattern.compile("(\\p{L})\\1\\1"),
106                            Pattern.compile("[Ii][iyq]"),
107                            Pattern.compile("[Yy]([aiu])\\1"),
108                            Pattern.compile("[Rr][uy]+[rh]"),
109                            Pattern.compile("[Qq]u[yu]"),
110                            Pattern.compile("[^oaei]uch"),
111                            Pattern.compile("[Hh][tcszi]?h"),
112                            Pattern.compile("[Tt]t[^aeiouy]{2}"),
113                            Pattern.compile("[Yy]h([^aeiouy]|$)"),
114                            Pattern.compile("([xqy])\\1$"),
115                            Pattern.compile("[qi]y$"),
116                            Pattern.compile("[szSZrlRL]+?[^aeiouytdfgkcpbmnslrv][rlsz]"),
117                            Pattern.compile("[UIuiYy][wy]"),
118                            Pattern.compile("^[UIui]e"),
119                            Pattern.compile("^([^aeioyl])\\1", 17)
120                    },
121            englishSanityChecks = new Pattern[]
122                    {
123                            Pattern.compile("[AEIOUaeiou]{3}"),
124                            Pattern.compile("(\\w)\\1\\1"),
125                            Pattern.compile("(.)\\1(.)\\2"),
126                            Pattern.compile("[Aa][ae]"),
127                            Pattern.compile("[Uu][umlkj]"),
128                            Pattern.compile("[Ii][iyqkhrl]"),
129                            Pattern.compile("[Oo][c]"),
130                            Pattern.compile("[Yy]([aiu])\\1"),
131                            Pattern.compile("[Rr][aeiouy]+[rh]"),
132                            Pattern.compile("[Qq]u[yu]"),
133                            Pattern.compile("[^oaei]uch"),
134                            Pattern.compile("[Hh][tcszi]?h"),
135                            Pattern.compile("[Tt]t[^aeiouy]{2}"),
136                            Pattern.compile("[Yy]h([^aeiouy]|$)"),
137                            Pattern.compile("[szSZrlRL]+?[^aeiouytdfgkcpbmnslr][rlsz]"),
138                            Pattern.compile("[UIuiYy][wy]"),
139                            Pattern.compile("^[UIui][ae]"),
140                            Pattern.compile("q(?:u?)$")
141                    },
142            japaneseSanityChecks = new Pattern[]
143                    {
144                            Pattern.compile("[AEIOUaeiou]{3}"),
145                            Pattern.compile("(\\w)\\1\\1"),
146                            Pattern.compile("[Tt]s[^u]"),
147                            Pattern.compile("[Ff][^u]"),
148                            Pattern.compile("[Yy][^auo]"),
149                            Pattern.compile("[Tt][ui]"),
150                            Pattern.compile("[SsZzDd]i"),
151                            Pattern.compile("[Hh]u"),
152                    },
153            arabicSanityChecks = new Pattern[]
154                    {
155                            Pattern.compile("(.)\\1\\1"),
156                            Pattern.compile("-[^aeiou](?:[^aeiou]|$)"),
157                    };

393    /*
394     * Removes accented characters from a string; if the "base" characters are non-English anyway then the result won't
395     * be an ASCII string, but otherwise it probably will be.
396     * <br>
397     * Credit to user hashable from http://stackoverflow.com/a/1215117
398     *
399     * @param str a string that may contain accented characters
400     * @return a string with all accented characters replaced with their (possibly ASCII) counterparts
401     *
402    public String removeAccents(String str) {
403        String alteredString = Normalizer.normalize(str, Normalizer.Form.NFD);
404        alteredString = diacritics.matcher(alteredString).replaceAll("");
405        alteredString = alteredString.replace('æ', 'a');
406        alteredString = alteredString.replace('œ', 'o');
407        alteredString = alteredString.replace('Æ', 'A');
408        alteredString = alteredString.replace('Œ', 'O');
409        return alteredString;
410    }*/
411
412    /**
413     * Removes accented Latin-script characters from a string; if the "base" characters are non-English anyway then the
414     * result won't be an ASCII string, but otherwise it probably will be.
415     *
416     * @param str a string that may contain accented Latin-script characters
417     * @return a string with all accented characters replaced with their (possibly ASCII) counterparts
418     */
419    public static CharSequence removeAccents(CharSequence str) {
420        CharSequence alteredString = str;
421        for (int i = 0; i < accentFinders.length; i++) {
422            alteredString = accentFinders[i].replace(alteredString);
423        }
424        return alteredString;
425    }
426
427    private FakeLanguageGen register(String languageName) {
428        summary = registry.size() + "@1";
429        registry.put(languageName,this);
430        name = languageName;
431        return copy();
432    }
433
434    private FakeLanguageGen summarize(String brief) {
435        summary = brief;
436        return this;
437    }

782    /**
783     * Swahili is one of the more commonly-spoken languages in sub-Saharan Africa, and serves mainly as a shared language
784     * that is often learned after becoming fluent in one of many other (vaguely-similar) languages of the area. An
785     * example sentence in Swahili, that this might try to imitate aesthetically, is "Mtoto mdogo amekisoma," meaning
786     * "The small child reads it" (where it is a book). A notable language feature used here is the redoubling of words,
787     * which is used in Swahili to emphasize or alter the meaning of the doubled word; here, it always repeats exactly
788     * and can't make minor changes like a real language might. This generates things like "gata-gata", "hapi-hapi", and
789     * "mimamzu-mimamzu", always separating with a hyphen here.
790     * <br>
791     * As an aside, please try to avoid the ugly stereotypes that fantasy media often assigns to speakers of African-like
792     * languages when using this or any of the generators. Many fantasy tropes come from older literature written with
793     * major cultural biases, and real-world cultural elements can be much more interesting to players than yet another
794     * depiction of a "jungle savage" with stereotypical traits. Consider drawing from existing lists of real-world
795     * technological discoveries, like https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_science_and_technology_in_Africa , for
796     * inspiration when world-building; though some groups may not have developed agriculture by early medieval times,
797     * their neighbors may be working iron and studying astronomy just a short distance away.
798     * <br>
799     * Kondueyu; ma mpiyamdabota mise-mise nizakwaja alamsa amja, homa nkajupomba.
800     */
801    public static final FakeLanguageGen SWAHILI = swahili().register("Swahili");

842    /**
843     * Imitation Somali, using the Latin alphabet. Due to uncommon word structure, unusual allowed combinations of
844     * letters, and no common word roots with most familiar languages, this may seem like an unidentifiable or "alien"
845     * language to most readers. However, it's based on the Latin writing system for the Somali language (probably
846     * closest to the northern dialect), which due to the previously mentioned properties, makes it especially good for
847     * mixing with other languages to make letter combinations that seem strange to appear. It is unlikely that this
848     * particular generated language style will be familiar to readers, so it probably won't have existing stereotypes
849     * associated with the text. One early comment this received was, "it looks like a bunch of letters semi-randomly
850     * thrown together", which is probably a typical response (the comment was made by someone fluent in German and
851     * English, and most Western European languages are about as far as you can get from Somali).
852     * <br>
853     * Libor cat naqoxekh dhuugad gisiqir?
854     */
855    public static final FakeLanguageGen SOMALI = somali().register("Somali");

1212    /**
1213     * Imitation Hindi, romanized to use the Latin alphabet using accented glyphs similar to the IAST standard.
1214     * Most fonts do not support the glyphs that IAST-standard romanization of Hindi needs, so this uses alternate
1215     * glyphs from at most Latin Extended-A. Relative to the IAST standard, the glyphs {@code "ṛṝḷḹḍṭṅṇṣṃḥ"} become
1216     * {@code "ŗŕļĺđţńņşĕĭ"}, with the nth glyph in the first string being substituted with the nth glyph in the second
1217     * string. You may want to get a variant on this language with {@link #removeAccents()} if you can't display the
1218     * less-commonly-supported glyphs {@code āīūĕĭáíúóŗŕļţĺđńñņśş}. For some time SquidLib had a separate version of
1219     * imitation Hindi that was accurate to the IAST standard, but this version is more usable because font support is
1220     * much better for the glyphs it uses, so the IAST kind was removed (it added quite a bit of code for something that
1221     * was mostly unusable).

1266    /**
1267     * Imitation Arabic, using mostly the Latin alphabet but with some Greek letters for tough transliteration topics.
1268     * It's hard to think of a more different (widely-spoken) language to romanize than Arabic. Written Arabic does not
1269     * ordinarily use vowels (the writing system is called an abjad, in contrast to an alphabet), and it has more than a
1270     * few sounds that are very different from those in English. This version, because of limited support in fonts and
1271     * the need for separate words to be distinguishable with regular expressions, uses somewhat-accurate digraphs or
1272     * trigraphs instead of the many accented glyphs (not necessarily supported by most fonts) in most romanizations of
1273     * Arabic, and this scheme uses no characters from outside ASCII.
1274     * <br>
1275     * Please try to be culturally-sensitive about how you use this generator. Classical Arabic (the variant that
1276     * normally marks vowels explicitly and is used to write the Qur'an) has deep religious significance in Islam, and
1277     * if you machine-generate text that (probably) isn't valid Arabic, but claim that it is real, or that it has
1278     * meaning when it actually doesn't, that would be an improper usage of what this generator is meant to do. In a
1279     * fantasy setting, you can easily confirm that the language is fictional and any overlap is coincidental; an
1280     * example of imitation Arabic in use is the Dungeons and Dragons setting, Al-Qadim, which according to one account
1281     * sounds similar to a word in real Arabic (that does not mean anything like what the designer was aiming for). In a
1282     * historical setting, FakeLanguageGen is probably "too fake" to make a viable imitation for any language, and may
1283     * just sound insulting if portrayed as realistic. You may want to mix ARABIC_ROMANIZED with a very different kind
1284     * of language, like GREEK_ROMANIZED or RUSSIAN_AUTHENTIC, to emphasize that this is not a real-world language.
1285     * <br>
1286     * Hiijakki al-aafusiib rihit, ibn-ullukh aj shwisari!
1287     */
1288    public static final FakeLanguageGen ARABIC_ROMANIZED = arabic().register("Arabic Romanized");

1409    /**
1410     * Somewhat close to Old Norse, which is itself very close to Icelandic, so this uses Icelandic spelling rules. Not
1411     * to be confused with the language(s) of Norway, where the Norwegian languages are called norsk, and are further
1412     * distinguished into Bokmål and Nynorsk. This should not be likely to seem like any form of Norwegian, since it
1413     * doesn't have the a-with-ring letter 'å' and has the letters eth ('Ðð') and thorn ('Þþ'). If you want to remove
1414     * any letters not present on a US-ASCII keyboard, you can use {@link Modifier#SIMPLIFY_NORSE} on this language or
1415     * some mix of this with other languages; it also changes some of the usage of "j" where it means the English "y"
1416     * sound, making "fjord" into "fyord", which is closer to familiar uses from East Asia like "Tokyo" and "Pyongyang".
1417     * You can also now use {@link #NORSE_SIMPLIFIED} directly, which is probably easiest.
1418     * <br>
1419     * Leyrk tjör stomri kna snó æd ðrépdápá, prygso?
1420     */
1421    public static final FakeLanguageGen NORSE = norse().register("Norse");

1695     * evil"). The name INFERNAL refers to Dante's Inferno and the various naming conventions used for residents of Hell

1699     * humans), we add in vowel splits as used in LOVECRAFT and DEMONIC, then add quite a few accented vowels. These
1700     * traits make the language especially well-suited for "deal with the Devil" written bargains, where a single accent
1701     * placed incorrectly could change the meaning of a contract and provide a way for a fiend to gain leverage.
1702     * <br>
1703     * Zézîzûth eke'iez áhìphon; úhiah îbbëphéh haîtemheû esmez...
1704     */
1705    public static final FakeLanguageGen INFERNAL = infernal().register("Infernal");

1868    /**
1869     * Imitation text from an approximation of Korean, using the Revised Romanization method that is official in South
1870     * Korea today and is easier to type. The text this makes may be hard to pronounce. Korean is interesting as a
1871     * language to imitate for a number of reasons; many of the sounds in it are rarely found elsewhere, it can cluster
1872     * consonants rather tightly (most languages don't; English does to a similar degree but Japanese hardly has any
1873     * groups of consonants), and there are many more vowel sounds without using tones (here, two or three letters are
1874     * used for a vowel, where the first can be y or w and the rest can be a, e, i, o, or u in some combination). Some
1875     * letter combinations possible here are impossible or very rare in correctly-Romanized actual Korean, such as the
1876     * rare occurrence of a single 'l' before a vowel (it normally only appears in Romanized text before a consonant or
1877     * at the end of a word).
1878     * <br>
1879     * Hyeop euryam, sonyon muk tyeok aengyankeon, koelgwaelmwak.
1880     */
1881    public static final FakeLanguageGen KOREAN_ROMANIZED = korean().register("Korean Romanized");

2050    /**

2054     * "bail", which also have regional differences in pronunciation). As the name would suggest, it strongly prefers
2055     * using the vowel "o", with it present in about half the groups, but doesn't have any preference toward or against
2056     * the other vowels it uses, "a", "e", "i", and "u". The consonants completely avoid hard sounds like "t" and "k",
2057     * medium-hard sounds like "g" and "b", and also sibilants like "s" and "z".  This should be fairly hard to
2058     * pronounce, but possible.

2098    /**
2099     * Fantasy/sci-fi language that could be spoken by some very-non-human culture that would typically be fitting for
2100     * an alien species. This alien language is meant to have an abrupt change mid-word for many words, with the suffix
2101     * of roughly half of words using the letter "e", which is absent from the rest of the language; these suffixes can
2102     * also use consonant clusters, which are similarly absent elsewhere. The suffixes would make sense as a historical
2103     * relic or as a linguistic holdout from a historical merger. As the name would suggest, it strongly prefers
2104     * using the vowel "u", with it present in about half the groups, and can use the umlaut accent "ü" on some vowels.
2105     * The consonants completely avoid hard sounds like "t" and "k", and don't cluster; they often have special marks.
2106     * This should be relatively easy to pronounce for an alien language, though the words are rather long.
2107     * <br>
2108     * Üweħid vuŕeħid deẃul leŋul waloyeyür; äyovavü...
2109     */
2110    public static final FakeLanguageGen ALIEN_U = alien_u().register("Alien U");

2190    /**
2191     * Fantasy language that tries to sound like the speech of a powerful and pompous dragon, using long, complex words
2192     * and a mix of hard consonants like "t" and "k", "liquid" consonants like "l" and "r", and sometimes vowel groups
2193     * like "ie" and "aa". It frequently uses consonant clusters involving "r". It uses no accented characters.
2194     * <br>
2195     * Vokegodzaaz kigrofreth ariatarkioth etrokagik deantoznik hragriemitaaz gianehaadaz...
2196     */
2197    public static final FakeLanguageGen DRAGON = dragon().register("Dragon");

2199    /**
2200     * Fantasy language based closely on {@link #DRAGON}, but with much shorter words normally and closing syllables
2201     * that may sound "rushed" or "crude", though it has the same general frequency of most consonants and vowels.
2202     * This means it still uses lots of "t", "k", and "r", can group two vowels sometimes, and when there's a consonant
2203     * in the middle of a word, it is often accompanied by an "r" on one or both sides. If used with
2204     * {@link NaturalLanguageCipher}, this will look very similar to DRAGON, because the syllable lengths aren't
2205     * determined by this object but by the text being ciphered. Still, the ends of words are often different. It is
2206     * called KOBOLD because, even though the original kobold myth was that of a goblin-like spirit that haunted cobalt
2207     * mines, the modern RPG treatment of kobolds frequently describes them as worshippers of dragons or in some way
2208     * created by dragons, but generally they're a sort of failure to live up to a dragon's high expectations. The feel
2209     * of this language is meant to be something like a dragon's speech, but much less "fancy" and rather curt.
2210     * <br>
2211     * Thritriz, laazak gruz kokak thon lut...
2212     */
2213    public static final FakeLanguageGen KOBOLD = new FakeLanguageGen(
2214            DRAGON.openingVowels, DRAGON.midVowels, DRAGON.openingConsonants, DRAGON.midConsonants, DRAGON.closingConsonants,
2215            new String[]{"ik", "ak", "ek", "at", "it", "ik", "ak", "ek", "at", "it", "ik", "ak", "ek", "at", "it", "et", "ut", "ark", "irk", "erk"},
2216            DRAGON.vowelSplitters, new int[]{1, 2, 3}, new double[]{5, 11, 1},
2217            0.1, 0.0, 0.0, 0.22, genericSanityChecks, true).register("Kobold");

2252    /**
2253     * Fantasy/sci-fi language that would typically be fitting for an insect-like species without a close equivalent to
2254     * human lips. This language emphasizes hard sounds such as 't' and 'k', uses some sibilants such as 's', 'sh', and
2255     * 'x', uses lots of 'r' sounds, includes trill sounds using 'rr' (as in Spanish), and uses primarily 'a' and 'i'
2256     * for vowels, with low complexity on vowels. Differs from {@link #ALIEN_E} by not having harder-to-explain click
2257     * sounds, and adjusting vowels/sibilants a fair bit.
2258     * <br>
2259     * Ritars tsarraxgits, krit trir istsak!
2260     */
2261    public static final FakeLanguageGen INSECT = insect().register("Insect");

2421    /**
2422     * Fantasy/sci-fi language that would potentially be fitting for a trade language spoken by various very-different
2423     * groups, such as creatures with tentacled faces who need to communicate with spider-elves and living crystals.
2424     * This language tries to use relatively few sounds so vocally-restricted species can speak it or approximate it,
2425     * but some of its sounds are uncommon. It uses "ng" as Vietnamese does, as a sound that can be approximated with
2426     * "w" but more accurately is like the sound at the end of "gong". It uses a breathy sound in many vowels,
2427     * represented by "h", and this is separate from (and can be combined with) lengthening the vowel by doubling it
2428     * ("a", "ah", "aa", and "aah" are different). The "x" sound can be approximated by any of the "kh" or "q" sounds
2429     * used in various human languages, or with its usage in English for "ks". This does separate some vowels with "'",
2430     * which can be a glottal stop as in Hawaiian or various other languages, or approximated with a brief pause.
2431     * <br>
2432     * Zrolmolurz, voluu, nguu yuh'ongohng!
2433     */
2434    public static final FakeLanguageGen DEEP_SPEECH = deepSpeech().register("Deep Speech");
2435    /**
2436     * Somewhat close to Old Norse, which is itself very close to Icelandic, but changed to avoid letters not on a
2437     * US-ASCII keyboard. Not to be confused with the language(s) of Norway, where the Norwegian languages are called
2438     * norsk, and are further distinguished into Bokmål and Nynorsk. This just applies {@link Modifier#SIMPLIFY_NORSE}
2439     * to {@link #NORSE}. This replaces eth ('Ðð') and thorn ('Þþ') with 'th' unless preceded by 's' (where 'sð' or 'sþ'
2440     * becomes "st") or followed by 'r' (where 'ðr' or 'þr' becomes 'fr'). It replaces 'Æ' or 'æ' with 'Ae' or 'ae', and
2441     * replaces 'Ö' or 'ö' with 'Ou' or "ou", which can change the length of a String relative to NORSE. It removes all
2442     * other accent marks (since the two-dot umlaut accent has already been changed, this only affects acute accents).
2443     * It also changes some of the usage of "j" where it means the English "y" sound, making "fjord" into "fyord", which
2444     * is closer to familiar uses from East Asia like "Tokyo" and "Pyongyang".
2445     * <br>
2446     * Leyrk tyour stomri kna sno aed frepdapa, prygso?
2447     */
2448    public static final FakeLanguageGen NORSE_SIMPLIFIED = norse().addModifiers(Modifier.SIMPLIFY_NORSE)
2449            .register("Norse Simplified");
2450

2604    /**
2605     * A rough imitation of the Crow language of the American Midwest, using some tone marks. Some of the orthography
2606     * rules aren't clear across Internet information about the language, so this really is a "fake" language it will be
2607     * generating, not the real thing at all. This considers 'x' to be the rough back-of-throat noise that isn't in
2608     * English other than in loanwords, like the Scottish "loch," and in names like the German "Bach." Doubled (to use
2609     * the linguistic term, geminated) consonants are pronounced for a longer time, and doubled vowels with the same
2610     * accent mark or no accent mark are also lengthened. An un-accented vowel has a normal tone, an accented vowel has
2611     * a high tone, and an accented vowel followed by an un-accented vowel has a falling tone. This last feature is the
2612     * least common among languages here, and is a good way of distinguishing imitation Crow from other languages.
2613     * <br>
2614     * Pashu-umíkiki; chinébúlu ak kóokutú shu-eníí-a ipíimúu heekokáakoku?
2615     */
2616    public static final FakeLanguageGen CROW = crow().register("Crow");

3054    /**
3055     * A very rough imitation of the Vietnamese language, without using the accurate characters Vietnamese really uses
3056     * but that are rare in fonts. Since so many letters in correct Vietnamese aren't available in most fonts, this
3057     * can't represent most of the accented vowels in the language, but it tries, with 6 accents for each of a, e, i, o,
3058     * and u, though none for y. It also uses 'ð' from Icelandic in place of the correct d with bar. This could also
3059     * maybe be used as an approximation of (badly) Romanized Thai, since Thai normally uses its own script but also has
3060     * many tones (which would be indicated by the accents here).
3061     * <br>
3062     * Bach trich, nŏ ngiukh nga cä tran ngonh... 
3063     */
3064    public static final FakeLanguageGen VIETNAMESE = vietnamese().register("Vietnamese");
3065
3066    /**
3067     * An array that stores all the hand-made FakeLanguageGen constants; it does not store randomly-generated languages
3068     * nor does it store modifications or mixes of languages. The order these are stored in is related to the numeric
3069     * codes for languages in the {@link #serializeToString()} output, but neither is dependent on the other if this
3070     * array is changed for some reason (which is not recommended, but not out of the question). If this is modified,
3071     * then it is probably a bad idea to assign null to any elements in registered; special care is taken to avoid null
3072     * elements in its original state, so some code may rely on the items being usable and non-null.
3073     */
3074    public static final FakeLanguageGen[] registered;
3075    public static final String[] registeredNames;
3076    static {
3077        // the first item in registry is null so it can be a placeholder for random languages; we want to skip it.
3078        registered = new FakeLanguageGen[registry.size()-1];
3079        registeredNames = new String[registered.length];
3080        for (int i = 0; i < registered.length; i++) {
3081            registeredNames[i] = registry.keyAt(i+1);
3082            registered[i] = registry.getAt(i+1);
3083        }
3084    }
3085
3086    /**
3087     * If a FakeLanguageGen is known and is in {@link #registered}, this allows you to look up that FakeLanguageGen by
3088     * name (using a name from {@link #registeredNames}).
3089     * @param name a String name such as "English", "Korean Romanized", or "Russian Authentic"
3090     * @return a FakeLanguageGen corresponding to the given name, or null if none was found
3091     */
3092    public static FakeLanguageGen get(String name)
3093    {
3094        return registry.get(name);
3095    }
3096    /**
3097     * If a FakeLanguageGen is known and is in {@link #registered}, this allows you to look up that FakeLanguageGen by
3098     * index, from 0 to {@code FakeLanguageGen.registered.length - 1}.
3099     * @param index an int from 0 to {@code FakeLanguageGen.registered.length - 1}
3100     * @return a FakeLanguageGen corresponding to the given index, or null if none was found
3101     */
3102    public static FakeLanguageGen getAt(int index)
3103    {
3104        return registry.getAt(index);
3105    }
3106    /**
3107     * If a FakeLanguageGen is known and is in {@link #registered}, this allows you to look up that FakeLanguageGen's
3108     * name by index, from 0 to {@code FakeLanguageGen.registeredNames.length - 1}.
3109     * @param index an int from 0 to {@code FakeLanguageGen.registeredNames.length - 1}
3110     * @return a FakeLanguageGen corresponding to the given index, or null if none was found
3111     */
3112    public static String nameAt(int index)
3113    {
3114        return registry.keyAt(index);
3115    }

3174    /**
3175     * This is a very complicated constructor! Maybe look at the calls to this to initialize static members of this
3176     * class, LOVECRAFT and GREEK_ROMANIZED.
3177     *
3178     * @param openingVowels        String array where each element is a vowel or group of vowels that may appear at the start
3179     *                             of a word or in the middle; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3180     * @param midVowels            String array where each element is a vowel or group of vowels that may appear in the
3181     *                             middle of the word; all openingVowels are automatically copied into this internally.
3182     *                             Elements may be repeated to make them more common
3183     * @param openingConsonants    String array where each element is a consonant or consonant cluster that can appear
3184     *                             at the start of a word; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3185     * @param midConsonants        String array where each element is a consonant or consonant cluster than can appear
3186     *                             between vowels; all closingConsonants are automatically copied into this internally.
3187     *                             Elements may be repeated to make them more common
3188     * @param closingConsonants    String array where each element is a consonant or consonant cluster than can appear
3189     *                             at the end of a word; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3190     * @param closingSyllables     String array where each element is a syllable starting with a vowel and ending in
3191     *                             whatever the word should end in; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3192     * @param vowelSplitters       String array where each element is a mark that goes between vowels, so if "-" is in this,
3193     *                             then "a-a" may be possible; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3194     * @param syllableLengths      int array where each element is a possible number of syllables a word can use; closely
3195     *                             tied to syllableFrequencies
3196     * @param syllableFrequencies  double array where each element corresponds to an element in syllableLengths and
3197     *                             represents how often each syllable count should appear relative to other counts; there
3198     *                             is no need to restrict the numbers to add up to any other number
3199     * @param vowelStartFrequency  a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that determines how often words start with vowels;
3200     *                             higher numbers yield more words starting with vowels
3201     * @param vowelEndFrequency    a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that determines how often words end with vowels; higher
3202     *                             numbers yield more words ending in vowels
3203     * @param vowelSplitFrequency  a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that, if vowelSplitters is not empty, determines how
3204     *                             often a vowel will be split into two vowels separated by one of those splitters
3205     * @param syllableEndFrequency a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that determines how often an element of
3206     *                             closingSyllables is used instead of ending normally
3207     */
3208    public FakeLanguageGen(String[] openingVowels, String[] midVowels, String[] openingConsonants,
3209                           String[] midConsonants, String[] closingConsonants, String[] closingSyllables, String[] vowelSplitters,
3210                           int[] syllableLengths, double[] syllableFrequencies, double vowelStartFrequency,
3211                           double vowelEndFrequency, double vowelSplitFrequency, double syllableEndFrequency) {
3212        this(openingVowels, midVowels, openingConsonants, midConsonants, closingConsonants, closingSyllables,
3213                vowelSplitters, syllableLengths, syllableFrequencies, vowelStartFrequency, vowelEndFrequency,
3214                vowelSplitFrequency, syllableEndFrequency, englishSanityChecks, true);
3215    }

3217    /**
3218     * This is a very complicated constructor! Maybe look at the calls to this to initialize static members of this
3219     * class, LOVECRAFT and GREEK_ROMANIZED.
3220     *
3221     * @param openingVowels        String array where each element is a vowel or group of vowels that may appear at the start
3222     *                             of a word or in the middle; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3223     * @param midVowels            String array where each element is a vowel or group of vowels that may appear in the
3224     *                             middle of the word; all openingVowels are automatically copied into this internally.
3225     *                             Elements may be repeated to make them more common
3226     * @param openingConsonants    String array where each element is a consonant or consonant cluster that can appear
3227     *                             at the start of a word; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3228     * @param midConsonants        String array where each element is a consonant or consonant cluster than can appear
3229     *                             between vowels; all closingConsonants are automatically copied into this internally.
3230     *                             Elements may be repeated to make them more common
3231     * @param closingConsonants    String array where each element is a consonant or consonant cluster than can appear
3232     *                             at the end of a word; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3233     * @param closingSyllables     String array where each element is a syllable starting with a vowel and ending in
3234     *                             whatever the word should end in; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3235     * @param vowelSplitters       String array where each element is a mark that goes between vowels, so if "-" is in this,
3236     *                             then "a-a" may be possible; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3237     * @param syllableLengths      int array where each element is a possible number of syllables a word can use; closely
3238     *                             tied to syllableFrequencies
3239     * @param syllableFrequencies  double array where each element corresponds to an element in syllableLengths and
3240     *                             represents how often each syllable count should appear relative to other counts; there
3241     *                             is no need to restrict the numbers to add up to any other number
3242     * @param vowelStartFrequency  a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that determines how often words start with vowels;
3243     *                             higher numbers yield more words starting with vowels
3244     * @param vowelEndFrequency    a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that determines how often words end with vowels; higher
3245     *                             numbers yield more words ending in vowels
3246     * @param vowelSplitFrequency  a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that, if vowelSplitters is not empty, determines how
3247     *                             often a vowel will be split into two vowels separated by one of those splitters
3248     * @param syllableEndFrequency a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that determines how often an element of
3249     *                             closingSyllables is used instead of ending normally
3250     * @param sane                 true to perform sanity checks for pronounce-able sounds to most English speakers, replacing many
3251     *                             words that are impossible to say; slows down generation slightly, irrelevant for non-Latin alphabets
3252     * @param clean                true to perform vulgarity/obscenity checks on the word, replacing it if it is too close to a
3253     *                             common English vulgarity, obscenity, or slur/epithet; slows down generation slightly
3254     */
3255    public FakeLanguageGen(String[] openingVowels, String[] midVowels, String[] openingConsonants,
3256                           String[] midConsonants, String[] closingConsonants, String[] closingSyllables, String[] vowelSplitters,
3257                           int[] syllableLengths, double[] syllableFrequencies, double vowelStartFrequency,
3258                           double vowelEndFrequency, double vowelSplitFrequency, double syllableEndFrequency,
3259                           Pattern[] sane, boolean clean) {
3260        this.openingVowels = openingVowels;
3261        this.midVowels = new String[openingVowels.length + midVowels.length];
3262        System.arraycopy(midVowels, 0, this.midVowels, 0, midVowels.length);
3263        System.arraycopy(openingVowels, 0, this.midVowels, midVowels.length, openingVowels.length);
3264        this.openingConsonants = openingConsonants;
3265        this.midConsonants = new String[midConsonants.length + closingConsonants.length];
3266        System.arraycopy(midConsonants, 0, this.midConsonants, 0, midConsonants.length);
3267        System.arraycopy(closingConsonants, 0, this.midConsonants, midConsonants.length, closingConsonants.length);
3268        this.closingConsonants = closingConsonants;
3269        this.vowelSplitters = vowelSplitters;
3270        this.closingSyllables = closingSyllables;
3271
3272        this.syllableFrequencies = new double[syllableLengths[syllableLengths.length - 1]];
3273        totalSyllableFrequency = 0.0;
3274        for (int i = 0; i < syllableLengths.length; i++) {
3275            totalSyllableFrequency += (this.syllableFrequencies[syllableLengths[i]-1] = syllableFrequencies[i]);
3276        }
3277
3278        if (vowelStartFrequency > 1.0)
3279            this.vowelStartFrequency = 1.0 / vowelStartFrequency;
3280        else
3281            this.vowelStartFrequency = vowelStartFrequency;
3282        if (vowelEndFrequency > 1.0)
3283            this.vowelEndFrequency = 1.0 / vowelEndFrequency;
3284        else
3285            this.vowelEndFrequency = vowelEndFrequency;
3286        if (vowelSplitters.length == 0)
3287            this.vowelSplitFrequency = 0.0;
3288        else if (vowelSplitFrequency > 1.0)
3289            this.vowelSplitFrequency = 1.0 / vowelSplitFrequency;
3290        else
3291            this.vowelSplitFrequency = vowelSplitFrequency;
3292        if (closingSyllables.length == 0)
3293            this.syllableEndFrequency = 0.0;
3294        else if (syllableEndFrequency > 1.0)
3295            this.syllableEndFrequency = 1.0 / syllableEndFrequency;
3296        else
3297            this.syllableEndFrequency = syllableEndFrequency;
3298        this.clean = clean;
3299        sanityChecks = sane;
3300        modifiers = new ArrayList<>(4);
3301    }
3302
3303    private FakeLanguageGen(String[] openingVowels, String[] midVowels, String[] openingConsonants,
3304                            String[] midConsonants, String[] closingConsonants, String[] closingSyllables,
3305                            String[] vowelSplitters, double[] syllableFrequencies,
3306                            double vowelStartFrequency, double vowelEndFrequency, double vowelSplitFrequency,
3307                            double syllableEndFrequency, Pattern[] sanityChecks, boolean clean,
3308                            List<Modifier> modifiers) {
3309        this.openingVowels = copyStrings(openingVowels);
3310        this.midVowels = copyStrings(midVowels);
3311        this.openingConsonants = copyStrings(openingConsonants);
3312        this.midConsonants = copyStrings(midConsonants);
3313        this.closingConsonants = copyStrings(closingConsonants);
3314        this.closingSyllables = copyStrings(closingSyllables);
3315        this.vowelSplitters = copyStrings(vowelSplitters);
3316        this.syllableFrequencies = Arrays.copyOf(syllableFrequencies, syllableFrequencies.length);
3317        this.vowelStartFrequency = vowelStartFrequency;
3318        this.vowelEndFrequency = vowelEndFrequency;
3319        this.vowelSplitFrequency = vowelSplitFrequency;
3320        this.syllableEndFrequency = syllableEndFrequency;
3321        for (int i = 0; i < syllableFrequencies.length; i++) {
3322            totalSyllableFrequency += syllableFrequencies[i];
3323        }
3324        if (sanityChecks == null)
3325            this.sanityChecks = null;
3326        else {
3327            this.sanityChecks = new Pattern[sanityChecks.length];
3328            System.arraycopy(sanityChecks, 0, this.sanityChecks, 0, sanityChecks.length);
3329        }
3330        this.clean = clean;
3331        this.modifiers = new ArrayList<>(modifiers);
3332    }

3334    private static String[] processParts(OrderedMap<String, String> parts, Set<String> missingSounds,
3335                                         Set<String> forbidden, IRNG rng, double repeatSingleChance,
3336                                         int preferredLimit) {
3337        int l, sz = parts.size();
3338        List<String> working = new ArrayList<>(sz * 24);
3339        String pair;
3340        for (int e = 0; e < parts.size(); e++) {
3341            Map.Entry<String, String> sn = parts.entryAt(e);
3342            if (missingSounds.contains(sn.getKey()))
3343                continue;
3344            for (String t : sn.getValue().split(" ")) {
3345                if (forbidden.contains(t))
3346                    continue;
3347                l = t.length();
3348                int num;
3349                char c;
3350                switch (l) {
3351                    case 0:
3352                        break;
3353                    case 1:
3354                        working.add(t);
3355                        working.add(t);
3356                        working.add(t);
3357                        c = t.charAt(0);
3358                        num = 0;
3359                        boolean repeat = true;
3360                        switch (c) {
3361                            case 'w':
3362                                num += 2;
3363                            case 'y':
3364                            case 'h':
3365                                num += 4;
3366                            case 'q':
3367                            case 'x':
3368                                num += 4;
3369                                repeat = false;
3370                                break;
3371                            case 'i':
3372                            case 'u':
3373                                repeat = false;
3374                                num = 13;
3375                                break;
3376                            case 'z':
3377                            case 'v':
3378                                num = 4;
3379                                break;
3380                            case 'j':
3381                                num = 7;
3382                                break;
3383                            default:
3384                                if (e >= preferredLimit)
3385                                    num = 6;
3386                                else
3387                                    num = 13;
3388                        }
3389                        for (int i = 0; i < num * 3; i++) {
3390                            if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.75) {
3391                                working.add(t);
3392                            }
3393                        }
3394
3395                        if (repeat && rng.nextDouble() < repeatSingleChance) {
3396                            pair = t + t;
3397                            if (missingSounds.contains(pair))
3398                                continue;
3399                            working.add(pair);
3400                            working.add(pair);
3401                            working.add(pair);
3402                            if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.7) {
3403                                working.add(pair);
3404                                working.add(pair);
3405                            }
3406                            if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.7) {
3407                                working.add(pair);
3408                            }
3409                        }
3410
3411                        break;
3412                    case 2:
3413                        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.65) {
3414                            c = t.charAt(1);
3415                            num = 0;
3416                            switch (c) {
3417                                case 'z':
3418                                    num = 1;
3419                                    break;
3420                                case 'w':
3421                                    num = 3;
3422                                    break;
3423                                case 'n':
3424                                    num = 4;
3425                                    break;
3426                                default:
3427
3428                                    if (e >= preferredLimit)
3429                                        num = 2;
3430                                    else
3431                                        num = 7;
3432                            }
3433                            working.add(t);
3434                            for (int i = 0; i < num; i++) {
3435                                if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.25) {
3436                                    working.add(t);
3437                                }
3438                            }
3439                        }
3440                        break;
3441                    case 3:
3442                        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.5) {
3443                            c = t.charAt(0);
3444                            switch (c) {
3445                                case 'z':
3446                                    num = 1;
3447                                    break;
3448                                case 'w':
3449                                    num = 3;
3450                                    break;
3451                                case 'n':
3452                                    num = 4;
3453                                    break;
3454                                default:
3455                                    if (e >= preferredLimit)
3456                                        num = 2;
3457                                    else
3458                                        num = 6;
3459                            }
3460                            working.add(t);
3461                            for (int i = 0; i < num; i++) {
3462                                if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.2) {
3463                                    working.add(t);
3464                                }
3465                            }
3466                        }
3467                        break;
3468                    default:
3469                        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.3 && (t.charAt(l - 1) != 'z' || rng.nextDouble() < 0.1)) {
3470                            working.add(t);
3471                        }
3472                        break;
3473                }
3474            }
3475        }
3476        return working.toArray(new String[0]);
3477    }

3492    public static FakeLanguageGen randomLanguage(long seed) {
3493        GWTRNG rng = new GWTRNG(seed);
3494        int[] lengths = new int[rng.between(3, 5)];
3495        System.arraycopy(new int[]{1, 2, 3, 4}, 0, lengths, 0, lengths.length);
3496        double[] chances = new double[lengths.length];
3497        System.arraycopy(new double[]{
3498                5 + rng.nextDouble(4), 13 + rng.nextDouble(9), 3 + rng.nextDouble(3), 1 + rng.nextDouble(2)
3499        }, 0, chances, 0, chances.length);
3500        double vowelHeavy = rng.between(0.2, 0.5), removalRate = rng.between(0.15, 0.65);
3501        int sz = openCons.size();
3502        int[] reordering = rng.randomOrdering(sz), vOrd = rng.randomOrdering(openVowels.size());
3503        OrderedMap<String, String>
3504                parts0 = new OrderedMap<>(openVowels),
3505                parts1 = new OrderedMap<>(openCons),
3506                parts2 = new OrderedMap<>(midCons),
3507                parts3 = new OrderedMap<>(closeCons);
3508        OrderedSet<String> forbidden = new OrderedSet<>(1024, 0.25f), missingSounds = new OrderedSet<>(64, 0.875f);
3509        parts1.reorder(reordering);
3510        parts2.reorder(reordering);
3511        parts3.reorder(reordering);
3512        parts0.reorder(vOrd);
3513        int n = 0;
3514
3515        int mn = Math.min(rng.nextInt(3), rng.nextInt(3)), sz0, p0s;
3516
3517        for (n = 0; n < mn; n++) {
3518            missingSounds.add(parts0.keyAt(0));
3519            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts0.getAt(0).split(" "));
3520            parts0.removeFirst();
3521        }
3522        p0s = parts0.size();
3523        sz0 = Math.max(rng.between(1, p0s + 1), rng.between(1, p0s + 1));
3524        char[] nextAccents = new char[sz0], unaccented = new char[sz0];
3525        int vowelAccent = rng.between(1, 7);
3526        for (int i = 0; i < sz0; i++) {
3527            nextAccents[i] = accentedVowels[vOrd[i + mn]][vowelAccent];
3528            unaccented[i] = accentedVowels[vOrd[i + mn]][0];
3529        }
3530        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.8) {
3531            for (int i = 0; i < sz0; i++) {
3532                char ac = nextAccents[i], ua = unaccented[i];
3533                String v = "", uas = String.valueOf(ua);
3534                Pattern pat = Pattern.compile("\\b([aeiou]*)(" + ua + ")([aeiou]*)\\b");
3535                Replacer rep = pat.replacer("$1$2$3 $1" + ac + "$3"), repLess = pat.replacer("$1" + ac + "$3");
3536                for (int j = 0; j < p0s; j++) {
3537                    String k = parts0.keyAt(j);
3538                    if (uas.equals(k)) // uas is never null, always length 1
3539                        v = parts0.getAt(j);
3540                    else {
3541                        String current = parts0.getAt(j);
3542                        String[] splits = current.split(" ");
3543                        for (int s = 0; s < splits.length; s++) {
3544                            if (forbidden.contains(uas) && splits[s].contains(uas))
3545                                forbidden.add(splits[s].replace(ua, ac));
3546                        }
3547                        parts0.put(k, rep.replace(current));
3548                    }
3549                }
3550                parts0.put(String.valueOf(ac), repLess.replace(v));
3551            }
3552        }
3553
3554        n = 0;
3555        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.75) {
3556            missingSounds.add("z");
3557            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("z").split(" "));
3558            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("z").split(" "));
3559            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("z").split(" "));
3560            n++;
3561        }
3562        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.82) {
3563            missingSounds.add("x");
3564            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("x").split(" "));
3565            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("x").split(" "));
3566            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("x").split(" "));
3567            n++;
3568        }
3569        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.92) {
3570            missingSounds.add("qu");
3571            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("qu").split(" "));
3572            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("qu").split(" "));
3573            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("qu").split(" "));
3574            n++;
3575        }
3576        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.96) {
3577            missingSounds.add("q");
3578            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("q").split(" "));
3579            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("q").split(" "));
3580            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("q").split(" "));
3581            n++;
3582        }
3583        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.97) {
3584            missingSounds.add("tl");
3585            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("tl").split(" "));
3586            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("tl").split(" "));
3587            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("tl").split(" "));
3588            n++;
3589        }
3590        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.86) {
3591            missingSounds.add("ph");
3592            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("ph").split(" "));
3593            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("ph").split(" "));
3594            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("ph").split(" "));
3595            n++;
3596        }
3597        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.94) {
3598            missingSounds.add("kh");
3599            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("kh").split(" "));
3600            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("kh").split(" "));
3601            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("kh").split(" "));
3602            n++;
3603        }
3604        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.96) {
3605            missingSounds.add("bh");
3606            missingSounds.add("dh");
3607            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("bh").split(" "));
3608            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("bh").split(" "));
3609            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("bh").split(" "));
3610            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("dh").split(" "));
3611            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("dh").split(" "));
3612            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("dh").split(" "));
3613            n++;
3614            n++;
3615        }
3616
3617        for (; n < sz * removalRate; n++) {
3618            missingSounds.add(parts1.keyAt(n));
3619            missingSounds.add(parts2.keyAt(n));
3620            missingSounds.add(parts3.keyAt(n));
3621            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.getAt(n).split(" "));
3622            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.getAt(n).split(" "));
3623            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.getAt(n).split(" "));
3624        }
3625
3626        return new FakeLanguageGen(
3627                processParts(parts0, missingSounds, forbidden, rng, 0.0, p0s),
3628                new String[]{},
3629                processParts(openCons, missingSounds, forbidden, rng, 0.0, 4096),
3630                processParts(midCons, missingSounds, forbidden, rng, (rng.nextDouble() * 3 - 0.75) * 0.4444, 4096),
3631                processParts(closeCons, missingSounds, forbidden, rng, (rng.nextDouble() * 3 - 0.75) * 0.2857, 4096),
3632                new String[]{},
3633                new String[]{}, lengths, chances, vowelHeavy, vowelHeavy * 1.8, 0.0, 0.0, genericSanityChecks, true).summarize("0#" + seed + "@1");
3634    }

3636    protected static boolean checkAll(CharSequence testing, Pattern[] checks) {
3637        CharSequence fixed = removeAccents(testing);
3638        for (int i = 0; i < checks.length; i++) {
3639            if (checks[i].matcher(fixed).find())
3640                return false;
3641        }
3642        return true;
3643    }

3645    /**
3646     * Checks a CharSequence, such as a String, against an overzealous vulgarity filter, returning true if the text
3647     * could contain vulgar elements or words that could seem vulgar or juvenile. The idea here is that false positives
3648     * are OK as long as there are very few false negatives (missed vulgar words). Does not check punctuation or numbers
3649     * that could look like letters.
3650     * @param testing the text, as a CharSequence such as a String, to check
3651     * @return true if the text could contain a vulgar or juvenile element; false if it probably doesn't
3652     */
3653    public static boolean checkVulgarity(CharSequence testing)
3654    {
3655        CharSequence fixed = removeAccents(testing);
3656        for (int i = 0; i < vulgarChecks.length; i++) {
3657            if (vulgarChecks[i].matcher(fixed).find())
3658            {
3659//                System.out.println(vulgarChecks[i]);
3660                return true;
3661            }
3662        }
3663        return false;
3664    }

3667     * Generate a word from this FakeLanguageGen, using and changing the current seed.
3668     *
3669     * @param capitalize true if the word should start with a capital letter, false otherwise
3670     * @return a word in the fake language as a String
3671     */
3672    public String word(boolean capitalize) {
3673        return word(srng, capitalize);
3674    }

3676    /**
3677     * Generate a word from this FakeLanguageGen using the specified long seed to use for a shared StatefulRNG.
3678     * If seed is the same, a FakeLanguageGen should produce the same word every time with this method.
3679     *
3680     * @param seed       the seed, as a long, to use for the randomized string building
3681     * @param capitalize true if the word should start with a capital letter, false otherwise
3682     * @return a word in the fake language as a String
3683     */
3684    public String word(long seed, boolean capitalize) {
3685        srng.setState(seed);
3686        return word(srng, capitalize);
3687    }
3688
3689    /**
3690     * Generate a word from this FakeLanguageGen using the specified RNG.
3691     *
3692     * @param rng        the RNG to use for the randomized string building
3693     * @param capitalize true if the word should start with a capital letter, false otherwise
3694     * @return a word in the fake language as a String
3695     */
3696    public String word(IRNG rng, boolean capitalize) {
3697        while (true) {
3698            sb.setLength(0);
3699            ender.setLength(0);
3700
3701            double syllableChance = rng.nextDouble(totalSyllableFrequency);
3702            int syllables = 1, i = 0;
3703            for (int s = 0; s < syllableFrequencies.length; s++) {
3704                if(syllableChance < syllableFrequencies[s])
3705                {
3706                    syllables = s + 1;
3707                    break;
3708                } else
3709                {
3710                    syllableChance -= syllableFrequencies[s];
3711                }
3712            }
3713            if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelStartFrequency) {
3714                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(openingVowels));
3715                if (syllables == 1)
3716                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(closingConsonants));
3717                else
3718                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midConsonants));
3719                i++;
3720            } else {
3721                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(openingConsonants));
3722            }
3723            String close = "";
3724            boolean redouble = false;
3725            if (i < syllables) {
3726                if (rng.nextDouble() < syllableEndFrequency) {
3727                    close = rng.getRandomElement(closingSyllables);
3728                    if (close.contains("@") && (syllables & 1) == 0) {
3729                        redouble = true;
3730                        syllables >>= 1;
3731
3732                        //sb.append(close.replaceAll("@\\d", sb.toString()));
3733                    }
3734                    if (!close.contains("@"))
3735                        ender.append(close);
3736                    else if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelEndFrequency) {
3737                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3738                        if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
3739                            ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
3740                                    .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3741                        }
3742                    }
3743                } else {
3744                    ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3745                    if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
3746                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
3747                                .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3748                    }
3749                    if (rng.nextDouble() >= vowelEndFrequency) {
3750                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(closingConsonants));
3751                        if (rng.nextDouble() < syllableEndFrequency) {
3752                            close = rng.getRandomElement(closingSyllables);
3753                            if (close.contains("@") && (syllables & 1) == 0) {
3754                                redouble = true;
3755                                syllables >>= 1;
3756
3757                                //sb.append(close.replaceAll("@\\d", sb.toString()));
3758                            }
3759                            if (!close.contains("@"))
3760                                ender.append(close);
3761                        }
3762                    }
3763                }
3764                i += vowelClusters.matcher(ender).findAll().count();
3765
3766            }
3767
3768            for (; i < syllables; i++) {
3769                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3770                if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
3771                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
3772                            .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3773                }
3774                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midConsonants));
3775            }
3776
3777            sb.append(ender);
3778            if (redouble && i <= syllables + 1) {
3779                sb.append(close.replaceAll("@", sb.toString()));
3780            }
3781
3782            if (sanityChecks != null && !checkAll(sb, sanityChecks))
3783            {
3784                continue;
3785            }
3786
3787            for (int m = 0; m < modifiers.size(); m++) {
3788                modifiers.get(m).modify(rng, sb);
3789            }
3790
3791            if (capitalize)
3792                sb.setCharAt(0, Character.toUpperCase(sb.charAt(0)));
3793
3794            if (clean && !checkAll(sb, vulgarChecks))
3795            {
3796                continue;
3797            }
3798            return sb.toString();
3799        }
3800    }

3804     * to use for a shared StatefulRNG.

3806     * this method.
3807     *
3808     * @param seed       the seed, as a long, to use for the randomized string building
3809     * @param capitalize true if the word should start with a capital letter, false otherwise
3810     * @param approxSyllables the approximate number of syllables to produce in the word; there may be more syllables
3811     * @return a word in the fake language as a String
3812     */
3813    public String word(long seed, boolean capitalize, int approxSyllables) {

3822     * @param capitalize true if the word should start with a capital letter, false otherwise

3824     * @return a word in the fake language as a String

3826    public String word(IRNG rng, boolean capitalize, int approxSyllables) {

3829    /**
3830     * Generate a word from this FakeLanguageGen with an approximate number of syllables using the specified long seed 
3831     * to use for a shared StatefulRNG. This takes an array of {@link Pattern} objects (from RegExodus, not
3832     * java.util.regex) that should match invalid outputs, such as words that shouldn't be generated in some context due
3833     * to vulgarity or cultural matters. If seed and the other parameters are the same, a FakeLanguageGen should produce
3834     * the same word every time with this method.
3835     *
3836     * @param seed       the seed, as a long, to use for the randomized string building
3837     * @param capitalize true if the word should start with a capital letter, false otherwise
3838     * @param approxSyllables the approximate number of syllables to produce in the word; there may be more syllables
3839     * @param additionalChecks an array of RegExodus Pattern objects that match invalid words (these may be additional vulgarity checks, for example)
3840     * @return a word in the fake language as a String
3841     */
3842    public String word(long seed, boolean capitalize, int approxSyllables, Pattern[] additionalChecks) {
3843        srng.setState(seed);
3844        return word(srng, capitalize, approxSyllables, additionalChecks);
3845    }

3847    /**
3848     * Generate a word from this FakeLanguageGen using the specified RNG with an approximate number of syllables.
3849     * This takes an array of {@link Pattern} objects (from RegExodus, not java.util.regex) that should match invalid
3850     * outputs, such as words that shouldn't be generated in some context due to vulgarity or cultural matters.
3851     *
3852     * @param rng        the RNG to use for the randomized string building
3853     * @param capitalize true if the word should start with a capital letter, false otherwise
3854     * @param approxSyllables the approximate number of syllables to produce in the word; there may be more syllables
3855     * @param additionalChecks an array of RegExodus Pattern objects that match invalid words (these may be additional vulgarity checks, for example)
3856     * @return a word in the fake language as a String
3857     */
3858    public String word(IRNG rng, boolean capitalize, int approxSyllables, Pattern[] additionalChecks) {
3859        if (approxSyllables <= 0) {
3860            sb.setLength(0);
3861            sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(openingVowels));
3862            for (int m = 0; m < modifiers.size(); m++) {
3863                modifiers.get(m).modify(rng, sb);
3864            }
3865            if (capitalize) sb.setCharAt(0, Character.toUpperCase(sb.charAt(0)));
3866            return sb.toString();
3867        }
3868        while (true) {
3869            sb.setLength(0);
3870            ender.setLength(0);
3871            int i = 0;
3872            if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelStartFrequency) {
3873                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(openingVowels));
3874                if (approxSyllables == 1 && closingConsonants.length > 0)
3875                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(closingConsonants));
3876                else if (midConsonants.length > 0)
3877                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midConsonants));
3878                i++;
3879            } else if (openingConsonants.length > 0) {
3880                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(openingConsonants));
3881            }
3882            String close = "";
3883            boolean redouble = false;
3884            if (i < approxSyllables) {
3885                if (closingSyllables.length > 0 && rng.nextDouble() < syllableEndFrequency) {
3886                    close = rng.getRandomElement(closingSyllables);
3887                    if (close.contains("@") && (approxSyllables & 1) == 0) {
3888                        redouble = true;
3889                        approxSyllables = approxSyllables >> 1;
3890
3891                        //sb.append(close.replaceAll("@\\d", sb.toString()));
3892                    }
3893                    if (!close.contains("@"))
3894                        ender.append(close);
3895                    else if (redouble && rng.nextDouble() < vowelEndFrequency) {
3896                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3897                        if (vowelSplitters.length > 0 && rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
3898                            ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
3899                                    .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3900                        }
3901                    }
3902                } else {
3903                    ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3904                    if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
3905                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
3906                                .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3907                    }
3908                    if (rng.nextDouble() >= vowelEndFrequency) {
3909                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(closingConsonants));
3910                        if (rng.nextDouble() < syllableEndFrequency) {
3911                            close = rng.getRandomElement(closingSyllables);
3912                            if (close.contains("@") && (approxSyllables & 1) == 0) {
3913                                redouble = true;
3914                                approxSyllables = approxSyllables >> 1;
3915
3916                                //sb.append(close.replaceAll("@\\d", sb.toString()));
3917                            }
3918                            if (!close.contains("@"))
3919                                ender.append(close);
3920                        }
3921                    }
3922                }
3923                i += vowelClusters.matcher(ender).findAll().count();
3924            }
3925
3926            for (; i < approxSyllables; i++) {
3927                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3928                if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
3929                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
3930                            .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3931                }
3932                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midConsonants));
3933            }
3934
3935            sb.append(ender);
3936            if (redouble && i <= approxSyllables + 1) {
3937                sb.append(close.replaceAll("@", sb.toString()));
3938            }
3939
3940            if (sanityChecks != null && !checkAll(sb, sanityChecks))
3941                continue;
3942
3943            for (int m = 0; m < modifiers.size(); m++) {
3944                modifiers.get(m).modify(rng, sb);
3945            }
3946
3947            if (clean && !checkAll(sb, vulgarChecks))
3948                continue;
3949
3950            if (additionalChecks != null && !checkAll(sb, additionalChecks))
3951                continue;
3952
3953            if (capitalize)
3954                sb.setCharAt(0, Character.toUpperCase(sb.charAt(0)));
3955
3956            return sb.toString();
3957        }
3958    }
